name: Romania
description: This culture is the result of ethnographic collection between 1896 and 1907 (the time of writing of the original source, [otescu1907]). The documentation of these 39 constellations was done by village teachers speaking to elderly locals, using sky charts with the standard Western constellations already marked. Line figures were collected for all constellations except the Pleiades cluster. The English translation which is available for [otescu1907] retains the detailed explanations for the constellations, but does not retain the original charts: it instead draws a simplified modern version excluding some minor stars. For the line figures, the leading source is then [crtro] unless otherwise specified. [crtro] is a modern Romanian digital exhibition based on the same [otescu1907]; this has detailed, individually drawn line figures over modern sky charts. Two constellations in Tau are identical, but with different names and semantics. Many stories describing these constellations are local, related to historical, agricultural, and religious traditions in Romania. Others are preserved from the Greek traditions.

constellations.certainty: This only includes the Big Dipper asterism, not the larger UMa.
constellations.description: It is said that the Emperor Trajan transported the Dacian prisoners to Rome with the Great Chariot, and the Dacian captains with the Little Chariot. There is also a Romanian legend explaining that God made this chariot move backwards to humble the charioteer.

constellations.certainty: Despite the group semantic, the stars are indeed lined: the three fainter stars into a triangle, which is linked to alf Aur.
[crtro] uses an invisible star to create a naturalistic handle to the tool; this is not included here. Only stars identified in [otescu1907] are included.
constellations.description: Traditional Romanian constellations that represent agricultural tools resemble (are naturalistic for) that tool.
The second name is because a monastery is also God's seat or chair. The names illustrate the religious component of the Romanian peasant view upon the sky.
Hora is a traditional Romanian folk dance, a symbol for the joy of life and for group membership, probably corresponding to an ancient ritual around the wheel of life.

names.english: The Emperor's Daughter with a Yoke

constellations.description: Altair is the girl. The other two stars form a yoke that supports the pails in which she carries water in order to refresh the souls of the sinful dead in hell.
Vega is the shepherd, and the four stars which seem to follow him, forming a quadrilateral, are the sheep.
The alternative name The Bell Board is a religious ritual object of great significance for Orthodox Christians.
It is said that the Roman Emperor Trajan transported the Dacian prisoners to Rome with the Great Chariot, and the Dacian captains with the Little Chariot.

constellations.certainty: Only the two heads are documented in the text of [otescu1907], and on the chart in [crtro].
constellations.description: The Romanians call these stars Romulus and Remus, reminiscent of the formation of Rome.

constellations.certainty: This line figure matches [crtro], so it does not include the end stars on the wings of modern Cyg.
constellations.description: Romanian peasants recognized in the Cygnus constellation the huge cross on which Jesus Christ was crucified.
This represents the beautifully adorned cross carried by the Orthodox priests from house to house at the beginning of the new year.

constellations.certainty: This includes alf02 Cap, which should be there according to both sources.
constellations.description: In the Romanian peasant imagination, when lightning strikes this sky region, rainy weather will surely follow.

A legend of the peasants in Argeș county says that while Jesus was on the cross, his torturers wanted to stick a nail in his navel. A crayfish came out of nowhere and stole the nail, thus thwarting their plan. In gratitude, Jesus blessed the animal by placing it in the sky.
This dragon is not the usual snake, but the local Zmeu or Balaur: a fearsome character in Romanian folk tales and ballads, which fights with Prince Charming.
In the Romanian peasant vision, the bird (together with The Dove) is linked to the tradition of Noah and the ark: the bird was sent to look for land after the flood.
In Romanian tales about the sky and stars, these are the scales used by Christ to weigh the sins of the people.

constellations.certainty: The shape of this line figure doesn't follow the IAU Vir lines, but is consistent in the Romanian sources.
constellations.description: The constellation is associated with the Virgin Mary. Spica is her heart.

constellations.certainty: The chart at [crtro] for this constellation is incorrect (it shows a different constellation). This line figure is then from [otescu1907].
constellations.description: These are the two fish that Jesus fed to thousands of people.
Only the horns of the animal are seen.

constellations.certainty: Note that alf Boo is not linked in, unlike in IAU Boo.
constellations.description: It is said to take care of the seven oxes identified in the brightest stars of Ursa Major.

constellations.certainty: Matches [otescu1907] instead of [crtro] (the shape is the same, but [otescu1907] uses bigger stars).
constellations.description: In the Romanian peasant vision, the bird (together with The Raven) is linked to the tradition of Noah and the ark: the bird was sent to look for land after the flood.

names.english: He Who Pours Out the Water

constellations.certainty: Matches the shape in [otescu1907], so is entirely connected.
Excludes the 7th, faint star in Orion's sword at one end of the sickle, which is called for in the sources but not clearly identifiable. It may be meant to be a star cluster in that region.

constellations.description: The tip of the auger is Betelgeuse, facing Pollux, star associated by Romanians with a treasure. The peasants believed that when the end of the world is near, the auger will pierce the treasure, releasing gold and solver brightness, but drying the world of water.

constellations.certainty: The triangle is closed, as shown in the sources. It represents only the head of the bull.

constellations.description: Associated with a hero (Prince Charming) who had to fight in the sky with the Balaur or Dragon constellation, and with the devil.

names.english: The Road of the Lost Men

constellations.description: Identified with the serpent who tempted Eve. Another name for this constellation is the Road of the Lost Men, on which the sinners will wander, bewildered at the second coming of Christ.

For Romanian peasants, who didn't know much about scorpions, this constellation represents Scorpia, a female-gendered fearsome monster with big, dangerous claws, thirsty for blood, who was thrown by the devil in front of the daring human who was trying to reach God [crtro].

In a Romanian sky legend, the axe is used by a charioteer to smash the head of a dead person which was thrown in front of him by the devil. The alternative name (Devil's Chariot) links to beliefs that this chariot used to transport the soil of the sinners to hell.
In Romanian traditions, the archer is seen as a Roman soldier.

In Romanian traditions, the saints are the so-called hierarchs: Vasile, Grigore, Ioan. Other documented names include The Three Kings (from the East), The Three Magi. Other local names recall a belt and sword, as in Western tradition.

* alf Tau.english: The Bright Star of the Pig
* alf Tau.description: When it rises, the swine wake and grunt, signalling that the day is approaching.
When it rises, the cockerels begin crowing.
